In my account to entertaine the benefit
Which youth in thee Cesario and ability
Might hope for and require, it were Injustice
To rob a gentleman deserving memory
Of Issue to preserve it.

sp.speaker: Ces.
sp.l: No more herein,
You are an excellent patterne of true piety,
Let me now turne your advocate. Pray looke into
The order of the Duke, Jnjoynd, admit
J satisfie the sentence without mariage
with you, how then?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Cesario.

sp.speaker: Ces.
sp.l: If I know
How to acquit your feares, yet keepe th'injunction
In every clause whole and entire, your charity
Will call me still your servant.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Still my son.

sp.speaker: Ces.
sp.l: Right Madam, now you have it, still your son.
The Genius of your blessings hath instructed
Your tongue oraculously, wee wil forget
How once I and Clarissa enterchangd
The tyes of brother and of sister, henceforth
New stile us man and wife.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: By what authority

sp.speaker: Ces.
sp.l: Heavens great appointment, yet in all my dotage
On thy perfections, when I thought Clarissa
Wee had beene pledges of one wombe, no loose
No wanton heat of youth, desir'd to claime
Priority in thy affections, other
Then nature might commend. Chastly I tendred
Thy farewell as a brother ought; but since
Our bloods are strangers, let our hearts contract
A long life-lasting unity, for this way
The sentence is to be observd or no way.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Then no way.

sp.speaker: Ces.
sp.l: I expected other answer Madam from you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: No, every age shall curse me,
The monster, and the prodigie of nature,
Horrors beyond extremity,

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Pray mother confine the violence of greife

sp.speaker: Ces.
sp.l: Yes mother, pray do.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Thus some catch at a matrons honor
By flying lust to plot Incestuous witchcrafts,
More terrible then whoredomes; cruell mercy
When to preserve the body from a death
The soule is strangled.

sp.speaker: Ces.
sp.l: This is more then passion.
It comes neere to distraction.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I am quieted.
Cesario, thou maiest tell the Duke securely
Albertos titles, honors and revenues,
The Duke may give away, Injoy them thou.
Clarissas birthright, Marianas dower
Thou shalt be Lord of; turne us to the world
Vnpittyed and unfreinded, yet my bed
Thou never sleep'st in; as for her; she heares me,
If she as much as in a thoughts consent;
That thou may'st call her wife, a Mothers curse
Shall never leave her.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: As a brother once
I lov'd you, as a noble freind yet honor ye,
But for a husband sir, I dare not owne you,
My faith is given already.

sp.speaker: Ces.
sp.l: To a Villaine, Ile cut his throat.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Why this is more then passion?
It comes neere a distraction.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Call to minde Sir.
How much you have abated of that goodnesse
Which once raign'd in ye, they appear'd so lovely
That such as freindship led to observation
Courted the great example.

sp.speaker: Ces.
sp.l: Left and flatterd into abroad derision

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Why dee thinke so?
My Lord Baptista, is your sonne growne cold
In hasting on the marriage, which his vowes
Have seald to my wrongd daughter?

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: Wee come Lady, to consummate the contract.

sp.speaker: Ces.
sp.l: With Mentivole? is he the man?

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: Clarissas, troth and mine,
Cesario are recorded in a character
So plaine and certaine, that except the hand
Of heaven, which writ it first, would blot it out againe,
No human power can raze it.

sp.speaker: Ces.
sp.l: But say you so too? young Lady,

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: I should els betray
My heart to falshood, and my tongue to perjury.

sp.speaker: Ces.
sp.l: Madam, you know the sentence.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: From the Duke,
I have particular comforts which require
A private eare.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I shall approve it gladly,
Wee are resolvd Cesario.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: Be not insolent upon a Princes favour.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Loose no glory,
Your younger yeares have purchast.

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: And deservd too y'have many worthy freinds.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.p: Preserve and use them. Exeunt: Manet Cesar.

sp.speaker: Ces.
sp.l: Good, very good, why here's a complement
Of mirth in desperation, I could curse
My fate. ô with what speed men tumble downe
From hopes that soare to high. Biancha now
May scorne me justly too, Clarissa married,
Albertos widdow resolute, Biancha
Refusd, and I forsaken, let me study,
I can but dye a Batchelor that's the worst on't. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Host, Taylor, Muliter, Dancer, Pedant, Coxcombe.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Come Gentlemen,
This is the day that our great artist hath
Promist to give all your severall suites satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Dancer.
sp.l: Is he stirring?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: He hath beene at his booke these two houres.

sp.speaker: Pedant.
sp.l: Hees a rare Physitian.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Why Ile tell you,
Were Paracelsus the German now
Living, heed take up his single rapier against his
Terrible long sword, he makes it a matter of nothing
To cure the goute, sore eyes he takes out as familiarly,
Washes them, and puts them in againe,
As you'd blanch almonds.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: They say he can make gold.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: I, I, he learnt it of Kelly in Germany.
There's not a Chimist
In christendome can goe beyond him for multiplying.

sp.speaker: Pedant.
sp.l: Take heed then,
He get not up your daughters belly my Host.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: You are a merry Gentleman
And the man of art will love you the better.

sp.speaker: Dancer.
sp.l: Does he love mirth and crotchets?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: O hees the most courteous Physitian,
You may drink or drab in's company freely,
The better he knowes how your disease growes,
The better he knowes how to cure it.

sp.speaker: Danc.
sp.l: But I wonder my Host
He has no more resort of Ladyes to him.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Why Sir?

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: O divers of them have great beleife in conjurers
Lechery is a great helpe to the quality.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Hee's scarce knowne to be in towne yet,
Ere long we shall have em come
hurring hither in Fetherbeds.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: How? bedridden.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: No sir, in fetherbeds that move upon 4 wheeles in Spanish caroches.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Pray acquaint him we give attendance.

sp.speaker: Host,
sp.l: I shall gentlemen. I would faine be rid
Of these rascalls, but that they raise profit
To my wine-seller;
When I have made use of them sufficiently,
I will intreat the conjurer to tye crackers to their tailes,
And send them packing.

div.stage: Enter Forobosco as in his Study. (A paper)

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: Come hither mine Host looke here.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: What's that?

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: A challenge from my man.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Forbreakings pate?

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: He writes here if I meet him not
ith Feild within this halfe houre,
I shall heare more from him.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: O sir, minde your profit,
Nere thinke of the rascall, here are the gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: Morrow my worthy clients,
What are you all prepard of your questions?
That I may give my resolution upon them,

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: We are sir.

sp.speaker: Pedant,
sp.l: And have brought our mony.

sp.speaker: Foro
sp.l: Each then in order,
And differ not for precedency.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: I am buying of an office sir,
And to that purpose I would faine learne
to dissemble cunningly.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: Doe you come to me for that? you should rather
Have gone to a cunning woman.

sp.speaker: Danc.
sp.l: I sir but their Instructions are but like women,
Pretty well but not to the depth, as i'do have it,
You are a conjurer, the devils master,
And I would learn it from you so exactly,

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: That the divill himselfe
Might not go beyond you,

sp.speaker: Danc.
sp.l: You are ith right sir.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: And so your mony for your purchase
Might come in againe within a 12 month.

sp.speaker: Danc.
sp.l: I would be a Graduate sir, no freshman.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: Here's my hand sir,
I will make you dissemble so methodically,
As if the divell should be sent from the great Turke,
In the shape of an Embassador
To set all the christian princes at variance.

sp.speaker: Danc.
sp.l: I cannot with any modesty desire any more,
There's your mony sir,

sp.speaker: Foco.
sp.l: For the art of dissembling.

sp.speaker: Cox.
sp.l: My suite sir will be newes to you when I tell it,

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: Pray on.

sp.speaker: Cox.
sp.l: I would set up a presse here in Italy,
To write all the Caranta for Christendome.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: That's newes indeed,
And how would you imploy me in't?

sp.speaker: Cox.
sp.l: Marry sir, from you
I would gaine my intelligence.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: I conceave you, you would have me furnish you
With a spirit to informe you.

sp.speaker: Cox.
sp.l: But as quiet a Divell as the woman,
The first day and a halfe after she's married,
I can by no meanes indure a terrible one.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: No, no, Ile qualifie him,
He shall not fright you,
It shall be the ghost of some lying Stationer,
sp.p: A Spirit shall looke as if butter would not melt in his mouth, A new Mercurius Gallobelgicus.

sp.speaker: Coxc.
sp.l: O there was a captaine was rare at it,

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: Nere thinke of him,
Though that captaine writ a full hand gallop,
And wasted indeed more harmelesse paper then
Ever did laxative Physick,
Yet wil I make you to out-scribble him,
And set downe what you please,
The world shall better beleeve you.

sp.speaker: Cox.
sp.l: Worthy sir I thanke you, there's mony.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: A new office
For writing pragmaticall Curranto's

sp.speaker: Pedant.
sp.l: I am a schoole-master sir,
And would faine conferre with you
About erecting 4 new sects of religion at Amsterdam.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: What the Divell should
New sects of religion doe there?

sp.speaker: Pedaot.
sp.l: I assure you I would get
A great deale of mony by it.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: And what are the 4 new sects
Of religion you would plant there?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Why that's it I come about sir,
Tis a Divel of your raising must invent 'em,
I confesse I am too weake to compasse it.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: So sir, then you make it a matter of no difficulty
To have them tolerated.

sp.speaker: Pedant.
sp.l: Trouble not your selfe for that,
Let but your Divel set them a foot once,
I have Weavers, and Ginger-bread makers,
And mighty Aquavitae-men, shall set them a going.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: This is somewhat difficult,
And will aske some conference with the divell.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Take your owne leasure sir,
I have another busines too, because I meane
To leave Jtaly, and bury my selfe in those neather parts
Of the low countries.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: What's that sir.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Marry I would faine make 9 dayes to the weeke, for the more ample benefit of the captaine.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: You have a shrewd pate sir.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: But how this might be compasd?

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: Compasd easily; tis but making
A new Almanacke, and dividing the compasse
Of the yeare into larger penny-worths,
As a Chandler with his compasse makes
A Geometrick proportion of the Holland cheese
He retailes by stivers.
But for getting of it licenc'd.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Trouble not your selfe with that sir,
There's your mony,

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: For foure new sects of religions,
And 9 dayes to the weeke.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: To be brought in at generall pay-dayes,
Write I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: At generall pay-dayes.

sp.speaker: Taylor.
sp.l: I am by profession a taylor,
You have heard of me.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: Yes sir, and will not steale from you
The least part of that commendation I have heard utterd.

sp.speaker: Taylor.
sp.l: I take measure of your worth sir,
And because I will not afflict you with any large bill
Of circumstances, I will snip off particulars.
I would faine invent some strange
And exquisite new fashions.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: Are you not travel'd sir.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Yes sir, but have observ'd all we can see
Or invent are but old ones with new names to'em,
Now I would some way or other grow more curious.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: Let me see to devise new fashions.
Were you never in the Moone?

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: In the Moone taverne! yes sir: often.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: No, I do meane in the new world,
In the world that's in the Moone yonder.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: How? a new world ith moone?

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: Yes I assure you.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: And peopled?

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: O most fantastically peopled.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Nay certaine then ther's worke for taylors?

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: That there is I assure you.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Yet I have talked with a Scotch taylor
That never discover'd so much to me,
Though he has travail'd far, and was a pedlar in Poland.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: That was out of his way,
This lies beyond China,
You would study new fashions you say?
Take my councell, make a voyage,
And discover that new world.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Shall I be a moon-man?

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: I am of opinion, the people of that world
(Jf they be like the nature of that climate they live in)
Do vary the fashion of their cloathes oftner then any
Quick-silver'd nation in Europe.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Not unlikely, but what should that be we call
The man in the moone then?

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: Why tis nothing but an Englishman
That stands there starke naked,
With a paire of sheires in one hand,
And a great bundle of broad cloath in the other
(Which resembles the bush of thornes)
Cutting out of new fashions.

sp.speaker: Taylor
sp.l: I have heard somewhat like this,
But how shall I get thither?

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: Ile make a new compasse shall direct you.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Certaine?

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: Count me else for no man of direction.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: There's 20 duckats in hand, at my returne
Ile give you a 100.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: A new voyage to discover new fashions.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.l: I have been a travailer too sir,
That have shewed strange beasts in Christendome,
And got mony by them, but I finde the trade to decay.
Your Camelion, or East-Indian hedg-hog
Gets very little mony, and your Elephant devoures
So much bread, brings in so little profit,
His keeper were better every morning
Cram 15 Taylors with white manchet,
I would have some new spectacle,
And one that might be more attractive.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: Let me see, were you ever in Spaine?

sp.speaker: Mule.
sp.p: Not yet Sir.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: I would have you go to Madrill, and against some great festivall, when the court lies there, provide a great and spacious Engilsh Oxe, and rode him whole, with a pudding in's belly; that would be the eight wonder of the world in those parts I assure you.

sp.speaker: Mule.
sp.p: A rare project without question.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: Goe beyond all their garlike olla Podrithoes, though you sod one in Garquentuas cauldron, bring in more mony, then all the monsters of Affrick.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Good Sir do your best for him; he's of my acquaintance, and one if ye knew him—

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: What is he?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: He was once a man of infinite letters.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: A Scholler?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: No sir, a packet carrier, which is alwaies a man of many letters, yon know: then he was Mule-driver, now hee's a gentleman, and feedes monsters.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: A most ungratefull calling.

sp.speaker: Mule.
sp.p: Ther's mony for your direction; the price of the Oxe Sir.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: A hundred French crownes, for it must be a Lincolne shire Oxe, and a prime one:
For a rare and monstrous spectacle, to be seen at Madrill.

sp.speaker: Hostes.
sp.p: Pray forbeare sir, we shall have a new quarrell.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: You durst not meet me ith' field, I am therefore come to spoyle your market.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: What's the newes with you sir.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Gentlemen, you that come hither to be most abominably cheated, listen, and be as wise as your plannet will suffer you, keep your mony, be not guld, be not laught at.

sp.speaker: Pedant.
sp.p: What meanes this? would I had my mony againe in my pocket.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: The fellow is full of malice, do not mind him.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: This profest cheating rogue was my master, and I confesse my selfe a more preternotorious rogue then himselfe, in so long keeping his villainous counsell.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: Come, come, I will not heare you.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: No couzner, thou wouldest not heare me, I do but dare thee to suffer me to speake, and then thou and all thy divells spit fire, and spoute Aqua fortis.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: Speake on, I freely permit thee.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Why then know all you simple animals, you whose purses are ready to cast the calfe, if they have not cast it already, if you give any credit this jugling rascal, you are worse then simple widgins, and will be drawne into the net by this decoy ducke, this tame cheater.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, pray marke him.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: He does professe Physicke, and counjuring; for his Physicke; he has but two medicins for all manner of diseases; when he was i'th low countryes, he us'd nothing but butterd beere, colourd with Allegant, for all kind of maladies, and that he called his catholick medcine; sure the ducth smelt out it was butterd beere, else they would never have endur'd it for the names sake: then does he minister a grated dogs turd instead of Rubarbe, many times of Vnicornes horne, which working strongly with the conceit of the Patient, would make them bescummer to the height of a mighty purgation.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: The rogue has studied this invective.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Now for his conjuring, the witches of Lapland are the divells chaire-women to him, for they will sell a man a winde to some purpose; he sells winde, and tells you fortye lyes over and over.

sp.speaker: Hostess.
sp.p: I thought what we should find of him.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Hold your prating, be not you an hereticke.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Conjure! Ile tell you, all the divells names he calls upon, are but fustian names, gatherd out of welch heraldry; in breife, he is a rogue of six reprieves, foure pardones of course, thrice pilloried, twice sung Lacrymae to the Virginalls of a carts taile, h'as five times been in the Gallies, and will never truly run himselfe out of breath, till he comes to the gallowes.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: You have heard worthy gentlemen, what this lying detracting rascall has vomited.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: Yes certaine, but we have a better trust in you, for you have taine our mony.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: I have so, truth is he was my servant, and for some chastisement I gave him, he does practise thus upon me; speake truly sirra, are you certaine I cannot conjure?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Conjure! ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: Nay, nay, but be very sure of it.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Sure of it? why Ile make a bargaine with thee, before all these gentlemen, use all thy art, all thy roguery, and make me do any thing before al this company I have not a mind to, Ile first give thee leave to claime me for thy bond slave, and when thou hast done hang me.

sp.speaker: Foro,
sp.p: Tis a match, sirra, Ile make you caper ith' aire presently.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: I have too solid a body, and my beleife is like a Puritans on Good-Friday, too high fed with capon.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: I will first send thee to Greeke land for a haunch of venison, just of the thicknesse of thine own tallow.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, Ile not stir an inch for thee.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: Thence to Amboyna ith' East-Jndies, for pepper to bake it.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: To Amboyna? so I might be pepperd.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: Then will I conveigh thee strark naked to Develing to beg a paire of brogs, to hide thy mountainous buttocks.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: And no doublet to 'em?

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: No sir, I intend to send you of a sleevelesse errand; but before you vanish, in regard you say I cannot conjure, and ar so stupid, and opinionated a slave, that neither I, nor my art can compell you to do any thing that's beyond your own pleasure, the gentlemen shall have some sport; you cannot endure a cat sirra?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: What's that to thee Iugler?

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: Nor you'l do nothing at my entreaty?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Ile be hang'd first.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: Sit Gentlemen, and whatsoever you see, be not frighted;

sp.speaker: Hostess:
sp.p: Alas I can endure no coniuring.

sp.speaker: Host:
sp.p: Stir not wife.

sp.speaker: Bian:
sp.p: Pray let me go sir, I am not fit for these fooleryes.

sp.speaker: Host:
sp.p: Move not daughter.

sp.speaker: For:
sp.p: I wil make you dance a new dance calld leap-frog.

sp.speaker: Clow:
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Fro:
sp.p: And as naked as a frog.

sp.speaker: Clow:
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, I defye thee.

div.stage: Foro. lookes in a booke, strikes with his wand, Musick playes. Enter 4. Boyes shap't like Frogs, and dance.

sp.speaker: Pedant:
sp.l: Spirits of the water in the likenes of frogs.
Tay: he has fisht faire beleeve me.

sp.speaker: Mule:
sp.p: See, see, he sweats and trembles.

sp.speaker: Foro:
sp.p: Are you come to your quavers?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Oh, oh, oh.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: Ile make you run division on that o's ere I leave you; looke you, here are the playfellowes that are so indeerd to you; come sir, first unease, and then dance, nay Ile make him daunce stark naked.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Oh let him have his shirt on, and his Mogols breeches, here are women ith' house.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: Well for their sakes he shall.

div.stage: Clown teares off his doublet, making strange faces as if compeld to it, falls into the Daunce.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: He daunces, what a lying rogue was this to say the gentleman could not conjure?

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: He does prettily well, but tis voluntary, I assure you, I have no hand in't.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: As you are a Counjurer, and a rare Artist, free me from these couplets; of all creatures I cannot endure a Frog.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: But your dauncing is voluntary, I can compell you to nothing.

sp.speaker: Hostes.
sp.p: O me, daughter, lets take heed of this fellow, he'le make us dance naked, an' we vex him.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: Now cut capers sirra, Ile plague that chin of yours.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Oh, oh, oh, my kidneys are rosted, I drop away like a pound of butter rosted.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: He will daunce himselfe to death.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: No matter Ile sell his fat to the Pothecaries, and repaire my injury that way.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Enough in conscience.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: Well, at your entreaty vanish. And now I wil only make him breake his neck in doing a sommerset, and that's all the revenge I meane to take of him.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: O gentlemen, what a rogue was I to belye so an approved Master in the noble dark science? you can witnesse, this I did only to spoyle his practise and deprive you of the happynesse of injoying his worthy labours; rogue that I was to do it, pray sir forgive me.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: With what face canst thou ask it?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: With such a face as I deserve, with a hanging looke, as all here can testifie.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: Well gentlemen, that you may perceive the goodnes of my temper, I will entertain this rogue again in hope of amendment, for should I turn him off, he would be hanged.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: You may read that in this foule coppy.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: Only with this promise, you shall never cozen any of my patients.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Never.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: And remember hence forward, that though I cannot counjure, I can make you daunce sirra, go get your selfe into the cottage againe. — Enter Caesario.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: I will never more daunce leape Frog: now I have got you into credit, hold it up, and cozen them in abundance.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: Oh rare rascall — Exit Clown.

sp.speaker: Cesar.
sp.p: How now, a Frankford mart here, a Mountebanke, and his worshipfull auditory.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: They are my ghuests Sir.

sp.speaker: Cesar.
sp.p: A— upon them, shew your jugling tricks in some other roome.

sp.speaker: Host,
sp.p: And why not here Sir?

sp.speaker: Cesar.
sp.p: Hence, or sirra I shall spoile your figure flinging, and all their radicall questions.

sp.speaker: Omnes
sp.p: Sir we vanish. — Exeunt. Manet Host. & Caesar.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Signior Caesario, you make bold with me,
And somewhat I must tell you to a degree
of ill manners, they are my ghuests, and men I live by,
And I would know by what authority
You command thus far.

sp.speaker: Cesar.
sp.p: By my interest in your daughter.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Interest do you call't? as J remember I never put her out to Vsury on that condition.

sp.speaker: Cesar.
sp.p: Pray thee be not angry.

sp.speaker: Hostes.
sp.l: I am come to make thee happy, and her happy:
Shee's here; alas my pretty soule, I am come
To give assurance that's beyond thy hope,
Or thy beleife, I bring repentance 'bout me,
And satisfaction, I will marry thee.

sp.speaker: Bianca.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Caesar.
sp.l: As I live I will, but do not entertain't
With too quick an apprehension of joy,
For that may hurt thee, I have heard some dye of't,

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: Do not feare me.

sp.speaker: Caesar
sp.l: Then thou think'st I faigne
This protestation, I will instantly
Before this testimony, my new alliance,
Contract my selfe unto thee, then I hope
We may be more private.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: But thou shalt not sir,
For so has many a maiden-head been lost, and many a bastard gotten,

sp.speaker: Ces.
sp.l: Then to give you the best of any assurance in the world,
Entreat thy father to goe fetch a Preist
Wee will instantly to bed, and there be married.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: Pride hath not yet fosaken you I see,
Though prosperity has.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Sir you are too confident
To fashion to your selfe a dreame of purchase
When you are a begger,

sp.speaker: Ces.
sp.l: you are bold with me.

sp.speaker: Hostes.
sp.l: Doe we not know your value is cried downe
Fourescore i'th hundred.

sp.speaker: Bian
sp.l: Oh sir I did love you
With such a fixed heart, that in that minute
Wherein you slighted, or contemn'd me rather,
I tooke a vow to obey your last decree,
And never more looke up at any hope
Should bring me comfort that way, and though since
Your Foster-mother, and the faire Clarissa
Have in the way of marriage despis'd you,
That hath not any way bred my revenge,
But compassion rather. I have found
So much sorrow in the way to a chaste wedlock
That here I will set downe, and never wish
To come to'th journies end. Your suite to mee
Henceforth be ever silenc't.

sp.speaker: Cesar.
sp.l: My Bianca.

sp.speaker: Hostes.
sp.l: Henceforward pray forbeare her and my house:
She's a poore vertuous wench, yet her estate
May weigh with yours in a gold balance.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Yes, and her birth in any Heralds office in Christendome.

sp.speaker: Hostes.
sp.l: It may prove so:
When you'l say, you have leapt a Whiteing. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ces,
sp.l: How far am I growne behind hand with fortune?

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: Here's Cesario:
My son sir is to morrow to be married
Vnto the faire Clarissa,

sp.speaker: Ces.
sp.l: So.

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: Wee hope youle be a gueste there?

sp.speaker: Ces.
sp.l: No I will not grace your triumph so much.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: I will not tax your breeding.
But it alters not your birth sir, fare you well.

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: Oh sir doe not greive him,
He has to much affliction already. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ces.
sp.l: Every way scorn'd and lost,
Shame follow you
For I am growne most miserable.

sp.speaker: Sail.
sp.l: Sir doe you know a Ladies son in towne here
They cal Cesario?

sp.speaker: Cesar.
sp.l: Ther's none such I assure thee;

sp.speaker: Sail.
sp.l: I was told you were the man.

sp.speaker: Cesar.
sp.l: What's that to thee?

sp.speaker: Sail.
sp.l: A— on't. You are melancholy, will you drink Sir?

sp.speaker: Cesar.
sp.l: With whom?

sp.speaker: Sail.
sp.p: With mee Sir; despise not this pitcht Canvas; the time was wee have knowne them lined with Spanish Duckets: I have news for you:

sp.speaker: Cesar.
sp.l: For me!

sp.speaker: Sail.
sp.l: Not unlesse you'l drink;
We are like our Sea provision, once out of pickle,
We require abundance of drink; I have news to tell you
That were you Prince,
Would make you send your mandate
To have a thousand bonfires made 'ith City,
And pist out agen with nothing but Greek wine.

sp.speaker: Cesar.
sp.l: Come, I wil drink with thee howsoever,

sp.speaker: Sail.
sp.p: And upon these terms I wil utter my mind to you. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter Alberoto, Prospero, Juliana, and Saylors.

sp.speaker: Sail.
sp.l: SHall we bring your necessaries ashore my Lord?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Do what you please, I am land-sicke, worse by far
Then ere I was at sea.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: Collect your selfe

sp.speaker: Alber.
sp.l: O my most worthy Prospero, my best friend,
The noble favor I receivd from thee
In freeing me from the Turks I now accompt
Worse than my death; for I shall never live
To make requitall; what doe you attend for?

sp.speaker: Sail.
sp.l: To understand your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Alber.
sp.l: They doe mock me;
I doe protest I have no kind of pleasure
In any thing i'th world, but in thy friendship,
I must ever except that.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.p: Pray leave him, leave him. — Exeunt Sailors.

sp.speaker: Alber.
sp.l: The newes I heard related since my landing
Of the division of my Family,
How is it possible for any man
To bear't with a set patience?

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: You have suffer'd
Since your imprisonment more waighty sorrowes.

sp.speaker: Alber.
sp.l: I, then I was a man of flesh and bloud,
Now I am made up of fire, to the full height
Of a deadly Calenture; ô these vild women
That are so ill preservers of mens honors,
They cannot governe their own honesties.
That I should thirty and odde winters feed
My expectation of a noble heire,
And by a womans falshood finde him now
A fiction, a meare dreame of what he was;
And yet I love him still.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: In my opinion
The sentence (on this tryall) from the Duke
Was noble, to repaire Cesarios losse
With the marriage of your wife, had you been dead.

sp.speaker: Alber.
sp.l: By your favor but it was not, I conceive
T'was disparagment to my name, to have my widdow
Match with a Faulkners son, and yet beleev't
I love the youth still, and much pitty him.
I doe remember at my going to Sea,
Vpon a quarrell, and a hurt receiv'd
From young Mentivole, my rage so farre
Oretopt my nobler temper, I gave charge
To have his hand cut off, which since I heard,
And to my comfort, brave Caesario,
Worthyly prevented.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: And 'twas nobly done.

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.l: Yet the revenge, for this intent of mine
Hath bred much slaughter in our families,
And yet my wife (which infinitly moanes me)
Intends to marry my sole heire Clarissa
To the head branch of the other faction.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: Tis the meane to work reconcilement.

sp.speaker: Alber.
sp.l: Betweene whom?

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: Your selfe, and the worthy Baptista.

sp.speaker: Alber.
sp.l: Never.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: O you have been of a noble and remarkable freindship,
And by this match tis generally in Florence
Hop'd, twill fully be reconcild; to me
'Twould be absolute content.

sp.speaker: Iulia.
sp.l: And to my selfe, I have maine interest in it.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Noble Sir, you may command my heart to breake for you
But never to bend that way; poore Caesario
When thou puft'st on thy mournfull willow garland,
Thy enemy shall be suted (I do vow)
In the same livery, my Caesario
Loved as my foster child, though not my sonne,
Which in some countryes formerly were barbarous,
Was a name held most affectionate; thou art lost,
Vnfortunate young man, not only slighted
Where thou received'st thy breeding, but since scorn'd
ith' way of marriage, by the poore Bianca
The In-keepers daughter.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: I have heard of that too;
But let not that afflict you; for this Lady
May happily deliver at more leasure
A circumstance may draw a faire event,
Better then you can hope for.
For this present we must leave you,
And shall visit you againe within these two houres.

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.l: Ever to me most welcome,— O my Caesario.

sp.speaker: Caesar.
sp.l: I am none of yours Sir, so tis protested;
And I humbly beg,
Since tis not in your power to preserve me
Any longer in a noble course of life,
Give me a worthy death.

sp.speaker: Alber.
sp.l: The youth is mad.

sp.speaker: Caesar.
sp.l: Nay Sir, I will instruct you in a way
To kill me honorably.

sp.speaker: Alber.
sp.l: That were most strange.

sp.speaker: Caesar.
sp.l: I am turning Pirate, You may be imployed
By the Duke to fetch me in; and in a sea-fight
Give me a noble grave.

sp.speaker: Alber.
sp.l: Questionlesse he's mad; I would give any Doctor
A thousand crownes to free him from this sorrow.

sp.speaker: Caesar.
sp.p: Here's the Physitian. — Shewes a Poniard

sp.speaker: Alber.
sp.l: Hold Sir, I did say
To free you from the sorrow, not from life.

sp.speaker: Caesar.
sp.l: Why life and sorrow are unseparable.

sp.speaker: Alber.
sp.l: Be comforted Caesario, Mentivole
Shall not marry Clarissa.

sp.speaker: Caesar.
sp.l: No Sir, ere he shall, Ile kill him.

sp.speaker: Alber.
sp.l: But you forfeit your own life then.

sp.speaker: Caesar.
sp.l: That's worth nothing.

sp.speaker: Alber.
sp.l: Caesario, be thy selfe, be mine Caesario,
Make not thy selfe uncapable of that portion
I have full purpose to confer upon thee;
By falling into madnesse, beare thy wrongs
With noble patience, the afflicted freind
Which ever in all actions crownes the end.

sp.speaker: Ces.
sp.l: You well awake me; nay recover'd me
Both to sence and full life, ô most noble sir,
Though I have lost my fortune, and lost you
For a worthy Father: yet I will not loose
My former vertue, my integrity
Shall not yet forsake me; but as the wilde Ivy,
Spredds and thrives better in some pittious ruin
Of tower, or defac'd Temple, then it does
Planted by a new building- so shall I
Make my adversity my instrument
To winde me up into a full content.

sp.speaker: Alber.
sp.l: Tis worthily resolv'd; our first adventure
Is to stop the marriage; for thy other losses,
Practis'd by a womans malice, but account them
Like conjurers windes rais'd to a fearefull blast,
And doe some mischeife, but do never last. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Now sir, will you not acknowledge that I have mightily advancte your practice?

sp.speaker: Forobos.
sp.p: Tis confest, and I will make thee a great man for't.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: I take a course to do that my selfe, for I drinke sack in abundance.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: O my rare rascall. We must remove.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Whither?

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: Any whither: Europe is to little to be cozned by us, I am ambitious to goe to the East-Indies, thou and I to ride on our brace of Elephants.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: And for my part I long to be in England agen; you wil never get so much as in England, we have shifted many countryes, and many names: but traunce the world over you shall never purse up so much gold as when you were in England, and call'd your selfe Doctor Lambe-stones.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: Twas an atractive name I confesse, women were then my only admirers.

sp.speaker: Clow,
sp.p: And all their visits was either to further their lust, or reveng injuries.

sp.speaker: Foro
sp.p: You should have forty in a morning beleager my closett, and strive who should be cozend first, amongst fourescore love-sick waighting women that has come to me in a morning to learne what fortune should betide them in their first marriage, I have found above 94 to have lost their maidenheads.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: By their owne confession, but I was faine to be your male midwife, and worke it out of them by circumstance.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: Thou wast, and yet for all this frequent resort of women and thy handling of their urinalls and their cases, thou art not given to lechery, what should be the reason of it? thou hast wholsome flesh enough about thee; me thinkes the divell should tempt thee too't.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: What need he do that, when he makes me his instrument to tempt others.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: Thou canst not chuse but utter thy rare good parts; thou wast an excellent baude I acknowledge.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Well, and what I have done that way I will spare to speake of all you and I have done sir, and though we should—

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: We will for England, that's for certaine.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: We shall never want there.

sp.speaker: Foro,
sp.p: Want? the Court of Wards shall want mony first, for I professe my selfe Lord Paramount over fooles and madfolkes.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Do but store your selfe with lyes enough against you come thither,

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: Why that's all the familarity I ever had with the Divell, my guift of lying, they say hees the Father of lyes, and though I cannot conjure, yet I professe my selfe to be one of his poore gossips. I will now reveale to thee a rare peece of service.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: What is it my most worshipful Doctor Lambstones.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: There is a Captaine come lately from Sea,
They call Prosper I saw him this morning
Through a chincke of wainscote that divides my lodging
sp.p: And the Host of the house, withdraw my Host, and Hostesse, the faire Biancha, and an antient gentlewoman into their bedchamber; I could not overheare their conference, but I saw such a masse of gold & Iewels, & when he had done he loc't it up into a casket; great joy there was amongst them & forth they are gone into the city, and my Host told me at his going forth he thought he should not returne till after supper; now sir, in their absence will we fall to our picklocks, enter the chamber, seize the Iewels, make an escape from Florence, and wee are made for ever.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: But if they should goe to a true conjurer, and fetch us back in a whirle winde?

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: Doe not beleeve there is any such fetch in Astrology, and this may be a meanes to make us live honest hereafter.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Tis but an ill road too't that lyes through the high way of theeving.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: For indeed I am weary of this trade of fortune-telling, and meane to give all over, when I come into England, for it is a very ticklish quality.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: And ith end will hang by a twine thred.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: Besides the Island has too many of the profession, they hinder one anothers market.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: No, no, the pillory hinders their market.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: You know there the jugling captaine.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: I there's a sure carde.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: Onely the fore-man of their jury is dead, but he dyed like a Roman.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Else tis thought he had made worke for the hangman.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: And the very Ball of your false prophets, hee's quasht too.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: He did measure the starres with a false yard, and may now travaile to Rome with a morter on's head to see if he can recover his mony that way.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: Come, come, lets fish for this casket, and to Sea presently.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: We shall never reach London I feare;
My minde runs so much of hanging landing at wapping.
This well may be a day of joy long wish'd for
To my Clarissa, shee is innocent.
Nor can her youth but with an open bosome
Meet Himens pleasing bounties, but to me
That am invirond with black guilt and horror
It does appeare a funerall though promising much
Jn the conception were hard to mannage
But sad in the event, it was not hate
But fond indulgence in me to preserve
Cesarios threatned life in open court
That forc'd me to disclaime him, choosing rather
To rob him of his birth-right, and honor
Then suffer him to run the hazard of
Inrag'de Baptistas fury, while he lives;
I know I have a sonne, and the Dukes sentence
A while deluded, and this tempest over,
When he assures himselfe despaire hath seizd him.
I can relieve and raise him— speake, who is it
That presses on my privacies? Sir your pardon.
You cannot come unwelcome, though it were
To reade my secret thoughts.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: Lady to you
Mine shall be ever open; Lady said I,
That name keeps too much distance, sister rather
I should have stilde you, and I now may claime it,
Since our divided families are made one
By this blessed marriage; to whose honor comes
The Duke in person, waited on by all
The braveries of his Coutt, to witnesse it,
And then to be our ghests, is the bride ready
To meet and entertaine him?

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: She attends the comming of your sonne.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: Pray you bring her forth.
The Dukes at hand— Musick in her loud voyce,
Speakes his arrivall.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: Shee's prepard to meet it. — Exit.

div.stage: Enter Mariana, Clarissa led by two Maides: at the other doore, Baptista meetes with Mentivole, led by two Courtiers, the Duke, Bishop; diverse Attendants: (A Song) whilst they salute.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: It were impertinent to wish you joy,
Since all joyes dwell about you, Himens torch
Was never slighted with a luckier omen,
Nor burnt with so much splendor, to defer
With fruitlesse complement, the meanes to make
Your certain pleasures lawfull to the world;
Since in the union of your hearts they are
Confirmd already: would but argue us
A boaster of our favours; to the Temple
And there the sacred knot once tyde, all t'riumphs
Our Dukedome can affoord, shall grace your nuptialls.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: On there.

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: I hope it is not in the power
Of any to crosse us now.

sp.speaker: Alber.
sp.l: But in the breath
Of a wrongd Father I forbid the bands.

sp.speaker: Cesar.
sp.l: What, doe you stand at gaze?

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: Risen from the dead!

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: Although the sea had vomitted up the figure
In which thy better part livd long imprisond,
True love despising feare, runs thus to meete it.

sp.speaker: Claris.
sp.l: In duty I kneele to it.

sp.speaker: Alber.
sp.l: Hence vile wretches,
To you I am a substance incorporeall,
And not to be prophand, with your vile touch?
That could so soone forget me, but such things
Are neither worth my anger, nor reproofe.
To you great sir, I turne my selfe and these
Immediate Ministers of your government,
And if in my rude language I transgresse;
Ascribe it to the cold remembrance of
My services, and not my rugged temper.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Speake freely, be thy language ne're so bitter,
To see thee safe Alberto, signes thy pardon.

sp.speaker: Alber.
sp.l: My pardon? I can need none, if it be not
Receivd for an offence. I tamely beare
Wrongs, which a slave-born Muscovite would check at.
Why if for treason I had beene deliverd
Vp to the hangmans Axe, and this dead trunck
Vnworthy of a Christian Sepulcher;
Exposd a prey to feed the ravenous vulture,
The memory of the much I oft did for you,
Had you but any touch of gratitude,
Or thought of my deservings, would have stopd you
From these unjust proceedings.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Heare the motives that did induce us.

sp.speaker: Alber.
sp.l: I have heard them all,
Your highnesse sentence, the whole Court abusd,
By the perjuries, and practise of this woman.
(Wee pest thou Crocodile) my hopefull son,
Whom I dare sweare mine owne, degraded of
The honors that descend to him from me:
And from that in his love scornd by a creature
Whose base birth though made eminent by her beauty,
Might well have markd her out Cesarios servant,
All this I could have pardond and forgot;
But that my daughter with my whole estate
So hardly purchasd, is assignd a dower;
To one whose Father, and whose family
I so detest; that I would loose my essence
And be transformed to a Basiliske
To look them dead, to mee's an injury,
Admits no satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: Ther's none offerd.

sp.speaker: Alber.
sp.l: Nor would not be accepted,
Though upon thy knees twere tenderd.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: Now the storme grows high.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: But that I thought thee dead, and in thy death
The brinie Ocean had entombd thy name;
I would have sought a wife in a Bordello
For my Mentivole, and gladly hugd
Her spurious Issue as my lawfull Nephewes,
Before his blood should ere have mixd with thine;
So much I scorne it.

sp.speaker: Alber.
sp.l: I'll not bandy words, but thus dissolve the contract.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: There I meet thee, and seize on what's mine owne.

sp.speaker: Alber.
sp.l: For all my service,
Great Sir grant me the combat with this wretch,
That I may scourge his insolence.

sp.speaker: Baptist.
sp.l: I kneele for it.

sp.speaker: Caesar.
sp.l: And to approve my selfe Albertos sonne,
Ile be his second upon any odds,
Gainst him that dare most of Baptistas race.

sp.speaker: Menti.
sp.l: Already upon honorable termes,
In me thou hast met thy better, for her sake
I'le adde no more.

sp.speaker: Alber.
sp.l: Sir, let our swords decide it.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: O stay Sir, and as you would hold the title
Of a just Prince, ere you grant licence to
These mad-mens fury, lend your private eare
To the most distres'd of women.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Speake, tis granted. He takes Mariana aside.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: In the meane time, let not Clarissa be
A patient looker on, though as yet doubtfull,
To whom to bend her knee first, yet to all
I stoop thus low in duty, and would wash
The dust of fury with my Virgin teares,
From his blessd feete, and make them beautifull
That would move to conditions of peace,
Though with a snaile like pace, they all are wingd
To beare you to destruction: reverend sirs,
Think on your ancient friendship caemented
With so much bloud, but shed in noble action,
Divided now in passion for a brawle;
The makers blush to own, much lov'd Caesario.
Brother, or friend, (each title may prevaile,)
Remember with what tendernesse from our child-hood
Wee lov'd together, you preferring me
Before your selfe, and I so fond of you
That it begot suspition in ill mindes
That our affection was incestuous.
Thinke of that happy time, in which I know
That with your deerest blood you had prevented
This showre of teares from me Mentivole,
My husband, registred in that bright star-chamber,
Though now on earth made strangers, be the example
And offer in one hande the peacefull Olive
Of concord, or if that can be denyed
By powerfull intercession in the other
Carry the Hermian rod and force atonement,
Now we will not bee all marble. Death's the worst then
And hee shall be my bridegroome, offers to kill her selfe

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: Hold Clarissa, his loving violence needs must
Offer inspite of honor — he snatches away her knife and sets it to his owne breast, she stayes his hand.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Was it to that end then on your religion?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: And my hope in heaven Sir.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Wee then will leave entreaties, and make use
Of our authority, must I cry ai-me
To this unheard of insolence? in my presence
To draw your swords, and as all reverence
That's due to majesty were forfeited,
cherish this wildernesse! sheath them instantly,
and shew an alteration in your lookes, or by my power

sp.speaker: Alber,
sp.l: Cut of my head

sp.speaker: Bapt.
sp.l: And mine, rather then heare of peace with this bad man.
I'le not alone give up my throat, but suffer
Your rage to reach my family.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: And my name to be no more remembred.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: What are these?

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.p: Biancha, tis Biancha, still Biancha: but strangely alter'd.

sp.speaker: Bapt.
sp.l: If that thirteene yeares
Of absence could raze from my memory
The figure of my freind, I might forget thee;
But if thy Image be graven on my heart,
Thou art my Prospero.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: Thou my Baptista?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: A suddaine change!

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: I dare not aske deere freind
If Juliana live! for that's a blessing
I am unworthy of, but yet deny not
To let me know the place she hath made happy
By having there her sepulcher.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: If your highnesse please to vouchsafe a patient
Eare wee shall make a true relation of a story
That shall call on your wonder.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Speake, wee heare you.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: Baptistas Fortune in the Genoa court,
His banishment, with his faire wifes restraint
You are acquainted with; what since hath follow'd
I faithfully will deliver, ere eight moones
After Baptistas absence were compleate,
Faire Juliana founde the pleasures that
They had injoy'd together were not barren,
And blushing at the burthen of her wombe,
No father neere to owne it, it drew on
A violent sicknesse, which call'd downe compassion
From the angry Duke, then carefull of her health.
Physitians were enquir'd of, and their judgment
Prescrib'd the Bathes of Luca as a meanes
For her recovery; to my charge it pleas'd her
To be committed; but as on the way
Wee journy'd, those throwes only knowne to women
Came thick upon her, in a private village.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: Shee died?

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: Have patience, she brought to the world
A hopefull daughter; for her bodies sicknesse
It soone decai'd, but the greife of her minde
Hourely increas'd, and life grew tedious to her,
And desperate ere to see you; she injoyn'd me
To place her in a Greeekish Monastery,
And to my care gave up her pretty daughter.

sp.speaker: Bapt.
sp.l: What monastery? as a Pilgrim bare-foot,
Ile search it out.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: Pray you interrupt me not,
Now to my fortunes; the girle well dispos'd off
With a faithfull freind of mine, my cruell fate
Made me a prisoner to the Turkish gallies,
Where for 12 yeares, these hands tugd at the oare,
But fortune tyr'd at length with my afflictions,
Some ships of Malta mett the Ottaman fleete,
Charg'd them and boorded them, and gave me freedome
With my deliverers I serv'd, and gott
Such reputation with the great Master
That he gave me command over a tall
And lusty ship, where my first happy service
Was to redeeme Alberto rumor'd dead,
But was like me surpris'd by Cortugogly.

sp.speaker: Alber.
sp.l: I would I had dyed there.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: And from him learning
Baptista liv'd, and their dissolved freindship,
I hois'd up sailes for Greece, found Iuliana
A votary at her beades; having made knowne
Both that you liv'd, and where you were, she borrow'd
So much from her devotion as to wish me
To bring her to you; if the object please you,
With joy receave her.

sp.speaker: Bapt.
sp.l: Rage and fury leave me- throwes away his sword
I am so full of happines, there's no room left
To entertaine you, O my long lost Iewell,
Light of mine eyes, my soules strength.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.l: My best Lord, having Embrac'd you thus,
Death cannot fright me.

sp.speaker: Bapt.
sp.l: Live long to do so though J should fix here.
Pardon me Prospero though I enquire my daughters fortune.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: That your happinesse
May be at all parts perfect, here she is!

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: Biancha daughter to a princesse.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: True with my faithfull Host I left her,
And with him till now she hath resided,
Ignorant both of her birth and greatnesse.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: O my blest one. Ioy upon joy over-whelmes me.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Above wonder.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: I doe begin to melt too, this strange story
Workes much upon me.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Since it hath ples'd heaven
To grace us with this miracle, I that am
Heavens instrument here, determine thus; Alberto
Be not unthankefull for the blessings showne you,
Nor you Baptista; discord was yet never
A welcome sacrifice; therefore rage layd by,
Embrace as freinds, and let pass'd difference
Be as a dreame forgotten.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: Tis to me.

sp.speaker: Alber.
sp.l: And me, and thus confirme it.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: And to tye it
In bonds not to be broken, with the marriage
Of young Mentivole, and faire Clarissa,
So you consent great Lady, your Biancha
Shall call Caesario Husband.

sp.speaker: Iulia.
sp.l: Tis a motion I gladly yeeld too.

sp.speaker: Caesar.
sp.p: One in which you make a sadd man happy. Offers to kneele.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: Kneele not, all forgiven.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: With the Duke your Vnkle I will make attonement, and will have no denyall.

div.stage: Enter Host, Forobosco, Clowne and Officers.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Let this day be still held sacred.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Now if you can conjure, let the Divell unbind you,

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: Wee are both undone,

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: Already wee feele it.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Iustice sir,

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: What are they?

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: I can resolve you, slaves freed from the Gallyes
By the Viceroy of Sicilia.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: What's their offence?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: The robbing me of all my plate and Iewels,
I meane the attempting of it,

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Please your grace I will now discover this varlet in earnest, this honest pestilent rogue, profest the art on conjuring, but all the skill that ever he had in the black art was in making a seacole fire; only with wearing strange shapes he begot admiration amongst fooles and women.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: Wilt thou preach thou varlet?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Why does he gogle with his eyes, and stauke so?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: This is one of his Magicall raptures.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: I doe vilifie your censure, you demand if I am guilty, whir sayes my cloake by a tricke so legerdemaine, now I am not guilty, I am guarded with innocence, pure silver lace I assure you.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Thus have I read to you your vertues, which notwithstanding I would not have you proud of.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: Out thou concealement of tallow, and counterfeit Mummia.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: To the Gallyes with them both.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: The onely sea physick for a knave ia to be basted in a gally with the oyle of a Bulls peesell.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: And will not you make a soure face at the same sauce, sirra? I hope to finde thee so leane, in one fortnight thou mayest be drawne by the eares through the hoop of a firkin.

sp.speaker: Duke,
sp.p: Divide them and away with them to'th Gallyes.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: This will take downe your pride Iugler.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: This day that hath given birth to blessings; beyond hope, admits no criminall sentence, to the Temple and there with humblenesse praise heavens bounties;
sp.l: For blessings nere discend from thence, but when
A sacrifice in thankes ascends from men. Exeunt omnes.

div.head: THE PROLOGVE.
div.l: Playes have their fates, not as in their true sence
They're understood, but as the influence
Of idle custome madly workes upon
The drosse of many tongu'd opinion.
A worthy story, how soever writ
For language, modest mirth, conceite or witt,
Meetes often times with the sweett commendation
Of hang't, tis scurvy, when for approbation
A Iigg shall be clapt at, and every rime
Prais'd and applauded by a clamorous chime.
Let Jgnorance and laughter dwell together,
They are beneath the Muses pitty. Hether
Come nobler Iudgements, and to those the straine
Of our invention is not bent in vaine.
The faire Maide of the Jnne to you commends
Her hopes and welcomes, and withall intends
In th' Entertaines to which she doth invite ye,
All things to please, and some things to delight yee.
